title: The Boston Tea Party
subtitle: Colonial Resistance Escalates (1773)
narrator: Thomas, age 15, apprentice to a Boston carpenter, 1773

sections.title: The Tea Act
sections.summary: My name is Thomas, and I am fifteen years old. I work as an apprentice carpenter in Boston, but tonight I'm about to become part of history. Parliament has passed the Tea Act, giving the British East India Company a monopoly on tea sales in the colonies.

sections.title: The Destruction of the Tea
sections.summary: Outside the meeting house, I see men disguising themselves as Mohawk Indians—a thin disguise of blankets, face paint, and feathers. It's meant to hide our identities and perhaps to symbolize that we're Americans, not British. I join them.

sections.title: The Intolerable Acts
sections.summary: Britain's response is swift and harsh. Parliament passes laws we call the Intolerable Acts. The Boston Port Act closes Boston Harbor until we pay for the tea—shutting down our economy.

sections.title: Colonial Unity Emerges
sections.summary: In September 1774, representatives from twelve colonies (all except Georgia) met in Philadelphia for the First Continental Congress. This was extraordinary—never before had the colonies united like this. Each colony had always looked after its own interests.

sections.title: The Point of No Return
sections.summary: Looking back now, I see that December night in 1773 as the point of no return. We'd protested before—boycotts, petitions, demonstrations. But dumping the tea was different.

vocabulary.definition: A 1773 protest where colonists dumped 342 chests of British tea into Boston Harbor to resist the Tea Act and taxation without representation.
A 1773 British law giving the East India Company a monopoly on colonial tea sales, including a tax that colonists opposed.
Harsh British laws punishing Massachusetts for the Boston Tea Party, including closing Boston Harbor and reducing colonial self-government.
Part of the Intolerable Acts, this law closed Boston Harbor until the city paid for the destroyed tea, devastating the local economy.
A meeting of representatives from the thirteen colonies to coordinate response to British policies. The First Continental Congress met in 1774.
Forcing colonists to provide housing and supplies for British soldiers in their homes.
